nodes.text: An input-aware selective instruction duplication (SID) framework can mitigate SDC coverage loss caused by input-dependent SDC propagation in HPC applications while remaining lightweight and efficient at runtime
Existing SID methods derive instruction vulnerability profiles from a single default reference input and assume vulnerability profiles are input-invariant

SDC propagation and instruction-level vulnerability are input-sensitive; different inputs can activate different control paths and data regions causing shifts in SDC patterns and leading to SDC coverage loss when using static SID

Protego: a framework that (a) performs a one-time FI-guided input search to find diverse inputs, (b) groups inputs into a small set of input groups with similar SID protection patterns, (c) trains a lightweight MLP on input-argument-derived features to predict group membership, and (d) at runtime selects and returns a pre-generated representative SID-protected executable for the predicted group
Protego avoids runtime fault injection or dynamic profiling by using offline-generated representative protected executables and lightweight input-argument features for runtime mapping

Empirical measurement across inputs for 10 HPC applications shows that static SID plans derived from a reference input often exhibit substantial SDC coverage loss across other inputs (coverage can drop from expected values e.g., 43% to 29% in examples)

Motivation and challenge: exhaustive per-input FI or dynamic profiling is impractical because the input space is massive and FI or profiling per input incurs costs comparable to or higher than full duplication

Offline FI-guided search: generate and evaluate 500 diverse inputs via mutation/crossover seeded search and FI campaigns to capture meaningful diversity in instruction-level SDC vulnerability profiles

Input grouping: cluster the 500 evaluated inputs into a small number of groups by minimizing maximum SDC coverage loss within groups; a 10% maximum allowable within-group coverage loss yields only a few groups per application

Feature selection and model: derive lightweight input-argument transformations, select top 5 features by mutual information, and train a 5-layer MLP to predict overall SDC vulnerability and map inputs to groups

Runtime operation: extract the 5 preselected features from a new input, run the MLP to predict estimated overall SDC rate, map to the nearest representative group, and promptly return the pre-generated representative SID-protected executable

Evaluation result: across 10 HPC applications and diverse inputs, Protego reduces average SDC coverage loss (reported example: from 21% to 10% across inputs in abstract and average reductions reported across protection levels in results) compared to existing static SID

Performance and cost tradeoffs: offline costs are one-time (search average ~3500 minutes, representative SID evaluation ~880 minutes across apps), model training is negligible (~6 seconds average), and runtime selection is fast (~0.05 s) yielding roughly 100x speedup over full duplication deployment time

Case study on high SDC-prone inputs: Protego substantially outperforms static SID when inputs exercise regions unseen by the reference input (example average coverage loss: baseline 22.89% vs Protego 6.41% across such inputs)

Conclusion: An offline FI-guided input grouping plus lightweight input-feature model enables practical runtime input-aware SID that significantly mitigates SDC coverage loss across diverse inputs while keeping runtime overhead low
